column3: 1)	" Miss Loomis
column4: I think it's very appropriate that the first question in this first debate of Campaign '80 should relate to the economy of the country
column5: because it seems to me that the people who are watching us tonight - 221 million Americans - are truly concerned about the poor rate of performance of the American economy over the last four years. Governor Reagan is not responsible for what has happened over the last four years
column6: nor am I. The man who should be here tonight to respond to those charges chose not to attend. But I want to answer as specifically as I can the question that you have just put to me. Let me tell you that I
column7: first of all
column8: oppose an election year tax cut
column9: whether it is the 10% across-the-board tax cut promised to the taxpayers by my opponent in this debate tonight
column10: or whether it is the $27.5 billion tax cut promised on the 20th of August by President Carter. I simply think that when we are confronting a budget deficit this year - and this fiscal year will end in about 10 days
column11: and we are confronted with the possibility of a deficit of $60 billion
column12: perhaps as much as $63 billion - that that simply would be irresponsible. That
column13: once again
column14: the printing presses will start to roll; once again we will see the monetization of that debt result in a higher rate of inflation. Even though we've seen some hopeful signs
column15: perhaps
column16: in the flash report on the third quarter
column17: that perhaps the economy is coming out of the recession
column18: we've also seen the rise in the rate of the prime; we have seen mortgage rates back up again
column19: a sure sign of inflation in the housing industry. What I would propose
column20: and I proposed it way back in March when I was a candidate in my own state of Illinois
column23: in cuts in the Federal budget. I think we've got to have fiscal restraint. And I said at that time that one of the things that we could do
column24: that perhaps would save as much as $5 billion to $7 billion
column25: according
column26: to one of the leading members of the House Budget Committee
column27: was to recalculate the index that is used to determine the cost of living benefits that are paid to civil service retirees
column28: to military retirees. That we ought to ... in addition to that
column29: we ought to pay those retirement benefits on the basis of once a year
column30: rather than twice a year
column31: and save $750 billion. In other words....

column1: I believe that the only unpopular measures
column3: that could be
column5: would be unpopular with the government
column6: and with those. perhaps
column7: some special interest groups who are tied closely to government. I believe that inflation today is caused by government simply spending more than government takes in
column8: at the same time that government has imposed upon business and industry
column9: from the shopkeeper on the corner to the biggest industrial plant in America
column10: countless harassing regulations and punitive taxes that have reduced productivity at the same time they have increased the cost of production. And when you are reducing productivity at the same time that you are turning out printing-press money in excessive amounts
column11: you're causing inflation. And it isn't really higher prices
column12: it's just
column13: you are reducing the value of the money. You are robbing the American people of their savings. And so
column14: the plan that I have proposed - and contrary to what John says
column15: my plan is for a phased-in tax cut over a three-year period
column16: tax increase and depreciation allowances for business and industry to give them the capital to refurbish plant and equipment
column17: research and development
column18: improved technology - all of which we see our foreign competitors having
column19: and we have the greatest percentage of outmoded industrial plant and equipment of any of the industrial nations - produce more
column20: have stable money supply
column21: and give the people of this country a greater share of their own savings. Now
column22: I know that this has been called inflationary by my opponent and by the man who isn't here tonight. But I don't see where it is inflationary to have people keep more of their earnings and spend it
column23: and it isn't inflationary for government to take that money away from them and spend it on the things it wants to spend it on. I believe we need incentive for the individual
column24: and for business and industry
column25: and I believe the plan that I have submitted
column26: with detailed backing
column27: and which has been approved by a number of our leading economists in the country
column28: is based on projections. conservative projections out for the next five years
column29: that indicates that this plan would
column31: result in a balanced budget. We have to remember
column32: when we talk a tax cut
column33: we're only talking about reducing a tax increase
column34: because this Administration has left us with a built-in tax increase that will amount to $86 billion next year.

column2: in addition to saying that this is no time for a tax cut
column3: in view of the incipient signs of renewed inflation
column4: in addition to calling for restraint in Federal spending
column6: I also suggested we ought to have an emergency excise tax on gasoline. I say that because I think
column7: this year
column8: we will send $90 billion out of this country to pay for imported oil
column9: even though that. those imports have been reduced. And since I first made that proposal 15 months ago
column10: the price of gasoline
column11: which was then $.80
column12: has gone up to about $1.30. In other words
column13: we've had a huge increase of about $.50 a gallon since that time
column14: and all of that increase has gone out of this country - or much of it - into the pockets of OPEC oil producers. Whereas I have proposed we ought to take. put that tax on here at home
column15: reduce our consumption of that imported oil. Recycle those proceeds
column16: then
column17: back into the pockets of the American workers by reducing their tax payments. their Social Security tax payments by 50%. That
column18: I think
column19: in addition
column20: would be an anti-inflationary measure that would strengthen the economy of this country.

column2: I cannot see where a $.50 a gallon tax applied to gasoline would have changed the price of gasoline. It would still have gone up as much as it has
column3: and the $.50 would be added on top of that. And it would be a tax paid by the consumers
column4: and then we're asked to believe that some way
column5: they would get this back to the consumers. But why? Why take it in the first place if you're going to give it back? Why not leave it with them? And John spoke about 15 years ago
column6: on the position that he. or 15 months ago
column7: on what he believed in. Fifteen months ago
column8: he was a cosigner and advocating the very tax cut that I am proposing
column9: and said that that would be a forward step in fighting inflation
column10: and that it would be beneficial to the working people of this country.

column14: I think
column15: is to ignore the fact. The fact is
column16: that in today's oil wells
column17: there is more oil still there than we have so far taken out and used. But it would require what is known as secondary or tertiary efforts to bring it out of the ground. And this is known oil reserves

column19: that is believed by the most knowledgeable oil geologists to contain probably more oil and natural gas than we have used so far since we drilled that first well 121 years ago. We have a coal supply that is equal to 50% of the world's coal supply

All of these things can be done. When you stop and think that we are only drilling on 2%. have leased only 2% of the possible. possibility for oil of the continental shelf around the United States; when you stop to think that the government has taken over 100 million acres of land out of circulation in Alaska

column12: and all the rest
column13: and that we really. all we have to do is to get the Government off the back of the oil industry
column14: and that's going to be enough. I agree with what I think is the major premise of your question
column15: sir
column16: that we are going to have to create a new conservation ethic in the minds of the American people. and that's simply why I proposed
column17: 15 months ago
column18: the emergency excise tax on gasoline that I did. I did it as a security measure to be sure
column19: because I would rather see us reduce the consumption of imported oil than have to send American boys to fight in the Persian Gulf. But at the same time
column20: I think it's going to take a dramatic measure of that kind to convince the American people that we will have to reduce the use of the private automobile. We simply cannot have people sitting one behind the wheel of a car in these long traffic jams going in and out of our great cities. We are going to have to resort to van pooling
column21: to car pooling. We're going to have to develop better community transportation systems
column22: so that with buses and light rail
column23: we can replace the private automobile in those places where it clearly is not energy-efficient. I think that

column25: when we are consuming

column29: the amount of energy that they consume in that country. Surely

column31: ;n the redesign of our homes
column32: not only of our houses
column35: that will make it possible for us to achieve. According to one study that was published a short time ago - the Harvard Business School study - indicated that just in the commercial sector alone of the economy
column36: we could save between 30% and 40% of the energy that we consume in this country today. So I think
column38: we will have to change in a very appreciable way
column39: some of the lifestyles that we now enjoy.

column3: I am not an enemy of conservation. I wouldn't be called a conservative if I were. But
column5: as the President himself challenged them after I made them

column10: and 19 years later
column11: told us we only had enough left for another 15 years. As for saving energy and conserving

column16: I think we are proving that we can go forward with conservation and benefit from that. But also
column17: I think it is safe to say that we do have sources of energy that have not yet been used or found.

States; when you stop to think that the government has taken over 100 million acres of land out of circulation in Alaska, alone, that is believed by geologists to contain much in the line of minerals and energy sources, then I think it is the Government, and the Government with its own restrictions and regulations, that is creating the energy crisis', 'That we are, indeed, an energyrich nation', because I would rather see us reduce the consumption of imported oil than have to send American boys to fight in the Persian Gulf', 'But at the same time, I think its going to take a dramatic measure of that kind to convince the American people that we will have to reduce the use of the private automobile', 'We simply cannot have people sitting one behind the wheel of a car in these long traffic jams going in and out of our great cities', 'We are going to have to resort to van pooling, to car pooling', 'Were going to have to develop better community transportation systems, so that with buses are things that we can do in the retrofitting, ;n the redesign of our homes, not only of our houses, but of our commercial structures, as well, that will make it possible for us to achieve', 'According to one study that was published a short time ago  the Harvard Business School study  indicated that just in the commercial sector alone of the economy, we could save between 30% and 40% of the energy that we consume in this country today', 'So I think, yes, we will have to change in a very appreciable way, some of the lifestyles that we now enjoy', 'Well, as Ive said, I am not an enemy of conservation', 'I wouldnt be called a conservative if I were', 'But, when my figures are challenged, as the President himself challenged them after I made them, I think it should be called to the attention of John and the others here that my figures are the figures of the Department of Energy, which has not been overly optimistic in recent years as to how much supply we have left', 'That is the same Government that, in 1920, told us we only had enough oil left for 13 years, and 19 years later, told us we only had enough left for another 15 years', 'As for saving energy and conserving, the American people havent been doing badly at that', 'Because in industry today, were producing more, over the last several years, and at 12% less use of energy than we were back in about 1973', 'And column4: I am well aware of the present deficiencies in the Armed Forces of this country. When you have a report
column6: that six out of 10 CONUS Divisions in this country - Continental United States Army Divisions - simply could not pass a readiness test: that two out of three divisions that were to be allocated to the so-called Rapid Deployment Force could not meet a readiness test. And in most cases
column7: that failure to meet the test was because of a lack of manning requirements
column8: an inability to fill many of the slots in those divisions. Yes
column9: I have seen figures that indicate that perhaps as of September
column10: 1980 - this very month - that there is a shortage of about 104
column11: 000 in the ranks between E-4 and E-9. And there were reports. public reports not long ago about ships that could not leave American ports because of a lack of crews. I talked to one of the leading former chiefs of Naval operations in my office a few weeks ago
column12: who told me about 25
column13: 000 Chief Petty Officers being short. But
column14: I think that that is clearly related to the fact that
column15: going back to the time when the all-volunteer Army was created in 1973 - and I worked hard for it and supported it - we simply have failed to keep pace with the cost of living. And today
column16: on the average
column17: the average serviceman is at least 15% - and I happen to think that's a very modest estimate - 15% below what has happened to the cost of living over that period of time. And as a result
column18: the families of some of our young servicemen are on food stamps today. And I think that's shocking; it's shameful. So
column19: yes
column20: I told the American Legion National! Convention
column21: the VFW National Convention - when I spoke to each of those bodies - I outlined a very specific program of increasing pay and allowances

column23: sir

column30: of course

column2: it's a shame now that there are only two of us here debating
column3: because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue
column4: and the only one who would be disagreeing with us is the President
column5: if he were present. I. too
column6: believe in the voluntary military. As a matter of fact
column7: today the shortages of non-commissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today
column8: we wouldn't have the non-commissioned officers to train the draftees. I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country
column9: when we want it to work. Recognize that we have a voluntary military. We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career
column10: and we're asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment. And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft
column11: working 100 hours a week at times
column12: and he's earning less for himself and his family
column13: while he's away from his family
column14: than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs
column15: working 40 hours a week here at home. As an aid to enlistment. we had an aid - 46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason
column16: the G.I. Bill of Rights - the fact that
column17: by serving in the military
column18: they could provide for a future college education. In 1977
column19: we took that away from the military. That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up. So I think it is a case of pay scale
column20: of recognizing that if we're going to have young men and women responsible for our security
column23: let's go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that we're asking of them. Along with this
column24: I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate. We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice
column25: and that would be also trained
column26: ready to use that type of equipment. Both of these
column28: would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people. The other day
column29: I just - I'll hasten - I just saw one example. Down in Texas. I saw a high school that is military.

column10: I do not support a boondoggle like the MX missile. I've just gotten a report from the Air Force that indicates that the 30-year lifecycle cost of that system is going to be $100 billion. The initial cost is about $54 billion
column11: and then when you add in the additional costs - not only the construction of the system

column6: believe in the voluntary military. As a matter of fact
column7: today the shortages of non-commissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today
column8: we wouldn't have the non-commissioned officers to train the draftees. I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country
column9: when we want it to work. Recognize that we have a voluntary military. We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career
column10: and we're asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment. And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft
column11: working 100 hours a week at times
column12: and he's earning less for himself and his family
column13: while he's away from his family
column14: than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs
column15: working 40 hours a week here at home. As an aid to enlistment. we had an aid - 46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason
column16: the G.I. Bill of Rights - the fact that
column17: by serving in the military
column18: they could provide for a future college education. In 1977
column19: we took that away from the military. That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up. So I think it is a case of pay scale
column20: of recognizing that if we're going to have young men and women responsible for our security
column23: let's go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that we're asking of them. Along with this
column24: I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate. We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice
column25: and that would be also trained
column26: ready to use that type of equipment. Both of these
column28: would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people. The other day
column29: I just - I'll hasten - I just saw one example. Down in Texas. I saw a high school that is military.

column9: I have seen figures that indicate that perhaps as of September
column10: 1980 - this very month - that there is a shortage of about 104
column11: 000 in the ranks between E-4 and E-9. And there were reports. public reports not long ago about ships that could not leave American ports because of a lack of crews. I talked to one of the leading former chiefs of Naval operations in my office a few weeks ago
column12: who told me about 25
column13: 000 Chief Petty Officers being short. But
column14: I think that that is clearly related to the fact that
column15: going back to the time when the all-volunteer Army was created in 1973 - and I worked hard for it and supported it - we simply have failed to keep pace with the cost of living. And today
column16: on the average
column17: the average serviceman is at least 15% - and I happen to think that's a very modest estimate - 15% below what has happened to the cost of living over that period of time. And as a result
column18: the families of some of our young servicemen are on food stamps today. And I think that's shocking; it's shameful. So
column19: yes
column20: I told the American Legion National! Convention
column21: the VFW National Convention - when I spoke to each of those bodies - I outlined a very specific program of increasing pay and allowances
column22: reenlistment bonuses. That only makes sense. But I would leave you with this thought
column23: sir
column24: to be quite specific in my answer to your question: that
column25: of course
column26: to protect the vital interests of this country
column27: if that became impossible; if I could not

column2: it's a shame now that there are only two of us here debating
column3: because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue
column4: and the only one who would be disagreeing with us is the President
column5: if he were present. I. too
column6: believe in the voluntary military. As a matter of fact
column7: today the shortages of non-commissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today
column8: we wouldn't have the non-commissioned officers to train the draftees. I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country
column9: when we want it to work. Recognize that we have a voluntary military. We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career
column10: and we're asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment. And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft
column11: working 100 hours a week at times
column12: and he's earning less for himself and his family
column13: while he's away from his family
column14: than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs
column15: working 40 hours a week here at home. As an aid to enlistment. we had an aid - 46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason
column16: the G.I. Bill of Rights - the fact that
column17: by serving in the military
column18: they could provide for a future college education. In 1977
column19: we took that away from the military. That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up. So I think it is a case of pay scale
column20: of recognizing that if we're going to have young men and women responsible for our security
column23: let's go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that we're asking of them. Along with this
column24: I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate. We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice
column25: and that would be also trained
column26: ready to use that type of equipment. Both of these
column28: would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people. The other day
column29: I just - I'll hasten - I just saw one example. Down in Texas. I saw a high school that is military.

column1: I'll catch up with it later.
Mr. Moyers. I must say that I think I have better opportunity
column3: of finding the necessary funds to pay what
column6: very substantial sums of money. We signed one bill. or we passed one bill
column7: just a couple of weeks ago in the House of Representatives for $500 million - a half a billion dollars. That is just a downpayment
column8: in my opinion. But
column9: unlike Governor Reagan
column10: I do not support a boondoggle like the MX missile. I've just gotten a report from the Air Force that indicates that the 30-year lifecycle cost of that system is going to be $100 billion. The initial cost is about $54 billion
column11: and then when you add in the additional costs - not only the construction of the system
column12: the missiles and the personnel
column13: and so on - when you add in the additional costs over the lifecycle of that system
column14: over $100 billion. I would propose to save the taxpayers of this country from that kind of costly boondoggle.

column3: with regard to that same missile system
column4: I happen to support and believe in the missile
column5: itself. But that's not the $54 billion cost that John is talking about. He's talking about that fantastic plan of the Administration to take thousands and thousands of square miles out in the Western states. And first
column6: he was going to dig a racetrack and have it going around in the racetrack so it would meet the requirements of SALT II treaty
column7: and now he's decided it'll have a straight up and down thing
column8: so it can he both verifiable and yet hideable from the Soviet Union. We need the missile
column9: I think
column10: because we are so out of balance strategically that we lack a deterrent to a possible first assault. But I am not in favor of the plan that is so costly. And therefore
column11: if I only had another second left
column12: I'd say that that high school class in a military training - 40 of its 80 graduates last year entered the United States service academies; West Point
column13: Annapolis and the Air Force Academy
column14: and to see those young men made me very proud to realize that there are young people in this country that are prepared to go into that kind of a career in service of their country.

keep pace with the cost of living', 'And today, on the average, the average serviceman is at least 15%  and I happen to think thats a very modest estimate  15% below what has happened to the cost of undefended', 'Mr Corddry, its a shame now that there are only two of us here debating, because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue, and the only one them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment', 'And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft, working 100 hours a week at times, and hes earning less for himself and his family, while hes away from his family, than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs, working 40 hours a week here at home', 'As an aid to enlistment', 'we had an aid  46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason, the GI', 'Bill of Rights  the fact that, by serving in the military, they could provide for a future college education', 'In 1977, we took that away from the military', 'That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up', 'So I think it is a case of pay scale, of recognizing that if were going to have young men and women responsible for our security, dealing with this sophisticated equipment, then for deteriorate', 'We need a millionman active reserve that could be called up on an instants notice, and that would be also trained, ready to use that type of equipment', 'Both of these, I think, would sums of money', 'We signed one bill', 'or we passed one bill, just a couple of weeks ago in the House of Representatives for $500 million  a half a billion dollars', 'That is just a downpayment, in my going to be $100 billion', 'The initial cost is about $54 billion, and then when you add in the additional costs  not only the construction of the system, the missiles and the personnel, and so on  when you add in the additional costs over the lifecycle of that system, over $100 billion', 'I would propose to save the taxpayers of this country from that kind of costly boondoggle', 'Well, let me just say that, with regard to that same missile system, I happen to support and believe in the missile, itself', 'But thats not the $54 billion cost that John is talking about', 'Hes talking about need the missile, I think, because we are so out of balance strategically that we lack a deterrent to a possible first assault', 'But I am not in favor of the plan that is so costly', 'And therefore, column3: 3)	" Mr. Corddry
column4: I am well aware of the present deficiencies in the Armed Forces of this country. When you have a report
column6: that six out of 10 CONUS Divisions in this country - Continental United States Army Divisions - simply could not pass a readiness test: that two out of three divisions that were to be allocated to the so-called Rapid Deployment Force could not meet a readiness test. And in most cases
column7: that failure to meet the test was because of a lack of manning requirements
column8: an inability to fill many of the slots in those divisions. Yes
column9: I have seen figures that indicate that perhaps as of September
column10: 1980 - this very month - that there is a shortage of about 104
column11: 000 in the ranks between E-4 and E-9. And there were reports. public reports not long ago about ships that could not leave American ports because of a lack of crews. I talked to one of the leading former chiefs of Naval operations in my office a few weeks ago
column12: who told me about 25
column13: 000 Chief Petty Officers being short. But
column14: I think that that is clearly related to the fact that
column15: going back to the time when the all-volunteer Army was created in 1973 - and I worked hard for it and supported it - we simply have failed to keep pace with the cost of living. And today
column16: on the average
column17: the average serviceman is at least 15% - and I happen to think that's a very modest estimate - 15% below what has happened to the cost of living over that period of time. And as a result
column18: the families of some of our young servicemen are on food stamps today. And I think that's shocking; it's shameful. So
column19: yes
column20: I told the American Legion National! Convention
column21: the VFW National Convention - when I spoke to each of those bodies - I outlined a very specific program of increasing pay and allowances
column22: reenlistment bonuses. That only makes sense. But I would leave you with this thought
column23: sir
column24: to be quite specific in my answer to your question: that
column25: of course
column26: to protect the vital interests of this country
column27: if that became impossible; if I could not
column28: despite the very best efforts that I asked the Congress to put forward
column29: to raise those pay and incentives and allowances
column30: of course
column31: I would not leave this country go undefended.

column2: it's a shame now that there are only two of us here debating
column3: because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue
column4: and the only one who would be disagreeing with us is the President
column5: if he were present. I. too
column6: believe in the voluntary military. As a matter of fact
column7: today the shortages of non-commissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today
column8: we wouldn't have the non-commissioned officers to train the draftees. I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country
column9: when we want it to work. Recognize that we have a voluntary military. We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career
column10: and we're asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment. And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft
column11: working 100 hours a week at times
column12: and he's earning less for himself and his family
column13: while he's away from his family
column14: than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs
column15: working 40 hours a week here at home. As an aid to enlistment. we had an aid - 46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason
column16: the G.I. Bill of Rights - the fact that
column17: by serving in the military
column18: they could provide for a future college education. In 1977
column19: we took that away from the military. That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up. So I think it is a case of pay scale
column20: of recognizing that if we're going to have young men and women responsible for our security
column23: let's go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that we're asking of them. Along with this
column24: I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate. We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice
column25: and that would be also trained
column26: ready to use that type of equipment. Both of these
column28: would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people. The other day
column29: I just - I'll hasten - I just saw one example. Down in Texas. I saw a high school that is military.

column1: I'll catch up with it later.
Mr. Moyers. I must say that I think I have better opportunity
column3: of finding the necessary funds to pay what
column6: very substantial sums of money. We signed one bill. or we passed one bill
column7: just a couple of weeks ago in the House of Representatives for $500 million - a half a billion dollars. That is just a downpayment
column8: in my opinion. But
column9: unlike Governor Reagan
column10: I do not support a boondoggle like the MX missile. I've just gotten a report from the Air Force that indicates that the 30-year lifecycle cost of that system is going to be $100 billion. The initial cost is about $54 billion
column11: and then when you add in the additional costs - not only the construction of the system
column12: the missiles and the personnel
column13: and so on - when you add in the additional costs over the lifecycle of that system
column14: over $100 billion. I would propose to save the taxpayers of this country from that kind of costly boondoggle.

column3: with regard to that same missile system
column4: I happen to support and believe in the missile
column5: itself. But that's not the $54 billion cost that John is talking about. He's talking about that fantastic plan of the Administration to take thousands and thousands of square miles out in the Western states. And first
column6: he was going to dig a racetrack and have it going around in the racetrack so it would meet the requirements of SALT II treaty
column7: and now he's decided it'll have a straight up and down thing
column8: so it can he both verifiable and yet hideable from the Soviet Union. We need the missile
column9: I think
column10: because we are so out of balance strategically that we lack a deterrent to a possible first assault. But I am not in favor of the plan that is so costly. And therefore
column11: if I only had another second left
column12: I'd say that that high school class in a military training - 40 of its 80 graduates last year entered the United States service academies; West Point
column13: Annapolis and the Air Force Academy
column14: and to see those young men made me very proud to realize that there are young people in this country that are prepared to go into that kind of a career in service of their country.

column4: I am well aware of the present deficiencies in the Armed Forces of this country. When you have a report

column7: that failure to meet the test was because of a lack of manning requirements
column8: an inability to fill many of the slots in those divisions. Yes
column9: I have seen figures that indicate that perhaps as of September
column10: 1980 - this very month - that there is a shortage of about 104
column11: 000 in the ranks between E-4 and E-9. And there were reports. public reports not long ago about ships that could not leave American ports because of a lack of crews. I talked to one of the leading former chiefs of Naval operations in my office a few weeks ago

column17: the average serviceman is at least 15% - and I happen to think that's a very modest estimate - 15% below what has happened to the cost of living over that period of time. And as a result

column2: it's a shame now that there are only two of us here debating
column3: because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue
column4: and the only one who would be disagreeing with us is the President
column5: if he were present. I. too
column6: believe in the voluntary military. As a matter of fact
column7: today the shortages of non-commissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today
column8: we wouldn't have the non-commissioned officers to train the draftees. I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country
column9: when we want it to work. Recognize that we have a voluntary military. We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career
column10: and we're asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment. And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft
column11: working 100 hours a week at times
column12: and he's earning less for himself and his family
column13: while he's away from his family
column14: than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs
column15: working 40 hours a week here at home. As an aid to enlistment. we had an aid - 46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason
column16: the G.I. Bill of Rights - the fact that
column17: by serving in the military
column18: they could provide for a future college education. In 1977
column19: we took that away from the military. That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up. So I think it is a case of pay scale
column20: of recognizing that if we're going to have young men and women responsible for our security
column23: let's go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that we're asking of them. Along with this
column24: I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate. We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice
column25: and that would be also trained
column26: ready to use that type of equipment. Both of these
column28: would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people. The other day
column29: I just - I'll hasten - I just saw one example. Down in Texas. I saw a high school that is military.

column17: the average serviceman is at least 15% - and I happen to think that's a very modest estimate - 15% below what has happened to the cost of living over that period of time. And as a result
column18: the families of some of our young servicemen are on food stamps today. And I think that's shocking; it's shameful. So
column19: yes
column20: I told the American Legion National! Convention
column21: the VFW National Convention - when I spoke to each of those bodies - I outlined a very specific program of increasing pay and allowances
column22: reenlistment bonuses. That only makes sense. But I would leave you with this thought
column23: sir
column24: to be quite specific in my answer to your question: that
column25: of course
column26: to protect the vital interests of this country
column27: if that became impossible; if I could not
column28: despite the very best efforts that I asked the Congress to put forward
column29: to raise those pay and incentives and allowances
column30: of course
column31: I would not leave this country go undefended.

column2: it's a shame now that there are only two of us here debating
column3: because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue
column4: and the only one who would be disagreeing with us is the President
column5: if he were present. I. too
column6: believe in the voluntary military. As a matter of fact
column7: today the shortages of non-commissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today
column8: we wouldn't have the non-commissioned officers to train the draftees. I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country
column9: when we want it to work. Recognize that we have a voluntary military. We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career
column10: and we're asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment. And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft
column11: working 100 hours a week at times
column12: and he's earning less for himself and his family
column13: while he's away from his family
column14: than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs
column15: working 40 hours a week here at home. As an aid to enlistment. we had an aid - 46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason
column16: the G.I. Bill of Rights - the fact that
column17: by serving in the military
column18: they could provide for a future college education. In 1977
column19: we took that away from the military. That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up. So I think it is a case of pay scale
column20: of recognizing that if we're going to have young men and women responsible for our security
column23: let's go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that we're asking of them. Along with this
column24: I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate. We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice
column25: and that would be also trained
column26: ready to use that type of equipment. Both of these
column28: would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people. The other day
column29: I just - I'll hasten - I just saw one example. Down in Texas. I saw a high school that is military.

column1: I'll catch up with it later.
Mr. Moyers. I must say that I think I have better opportunity
column3: of finding the necessary funds to pay what
column6: very substantial sums of money. We signed one bill. or we passed one bill
column7: just a couple of weeks ago in the House of Representatives for $500 million - a half a billion dollars. That is just a downpayment
column8: in my opinion. But
column9: unlike Governor Reagan
column10: I do not support a boondoggle like the MX missile. I've just gotten a report from the Air Force that indicates that the 30-year lifecycle cost of that system is going to be $100 billion. The initial cost is about $54 billion
column11: and then when you add in the additional costs - not only the construction of the system
column12: the missiles and the personnel
column13: and so on - when you add in the additional costs over the lifecycle of that system
column14: over $100 billion. I would propose to save the taxpayers of this country from that kind of costly boondoggle.

column3: with regard to that same missile system
column4: I happen to support and believe in the missile
column5: itself. But that's not the $54 billion cost that John is talking about. He's talking about that fantastic plan of the Administration to take thousands and thousands of square miles out in the Western states. And first
column6: he was going to dig a racetrack and have it going around in the racetrack so it would meet the requirements of SALT II treaty
column7: and now he's decided it'll have a straight up and down thing
column8: so it can he both verifiable and yet hideable from the Soviet Union. We need the missile
column9: I think
column10: because we are so out of balance strategically that we lack a deterrent to a possible first assault. But I am not in favor of the plan that is so costly. And therefore
column11: if I only had another second left
column12: I'd say that that high school class in a military training - 40 of its 80 graduates last year entered the United States service academies; West Point
column13: Annapolis and the Air Force Academy
column14: and to see those young men made me very proud to realize that there are young people in this country that are prepared to go into that kind of a career in service of their country.

that six out of 10 CONUS Divisions in this country  Continental United States Army Divisions  simply could not pass a readiness test: that two out of three divisions that were to be allocated to the socalled Rapid Deployment Force could not meet a readiness test', 'And in most cases, that failure to meet the test was because of a lack of manning requirements, an inability to fill many of the slots in those divisions', 'Yes, I have seen figures that indicate that perhaps as of September, 1980  this very month  that there is a shortage of about 104,000 in the ranks between E4 and E9', 'And there were reports', 'public reports not long ago about ships that could not leave American ports because of a lack of crews', 'I talked to one of the leading former chiefs of Naval operations in my office a few weeks ago, who told me about 25,000 Chief Petty Officers being short', 'But, I think that that is clearly related to the fact that, going back to the time when the allvolunteer Army was created in 1973  and I worked hard for it and supported it  we simply have failed to keep pace with the cost of living', 'And today, on the average, the average serviceman is at least 15%  and I happen to think thats a very modest estimate  15% below what has happened to the cost of living over that period of time', 'And as a result, the families of some of our young servicemen are on food stamps today', 'And I think thats shocking; its shameful', 'So, yes, I told the American Legion National!', 'Convention, the VFW National Convention  when I spoke to each of those bodies  I outlined a very specific program of increasing pay and allowances, reenlistment bonuses', 'That only makes sense', 'But I would leave you with this thought, sir, to be quite specific in my answer to your question: that, of course, to protect the vital interests of this country, if that became impossible; if I could not, despite the very best efforts that I asked the Congress to put forward, to raise those pay and incentives and allowances, of course, I would not leave this country go undefended', 'Mr Corddry, its a shame now that there are only two of us here debating, because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue, and the only one who would be disagreeing with us is the President, if he were present', 'I too, believe in the voluntary military', 'As a matter of fact, today the shortages of noncommissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today, we wouldnt have the noncommissioned officers to train the draftees', 'I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country, when we want it to work', 'Recognize that we have a voluntary military', 'We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career, and were asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment', 'And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft, working 100 hours a week at times, and hes earning less for himself and his family, while hes away from his family, than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs, working 40 hours a week here at home', 'As an aid to enlistment', 'we had an aid  46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason, the GI', 'Bill of Rights  the fact that, by serving in the military, they could provide for a future college education', 'In 1977, we took that away from the military', 'That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up', 'So I think it is a case of pay scale, of recognizing that if were going to have young men and women responsible for our security, dealing with this sophisticated equipment, then for heavens sakes, lets go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that were asking of them', 'Along with this, I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate', 'We need a millionman active reserve that could be called up on an instants notice, and that would be also trained, ready to use that type of equipment', 'Both of these, I think, would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people', 'The other day, I just  Ill hasten  I just saw one example', 'Down in Texas', 'I saw a high school that is military', 'Fine', 'Ill catch up with it later', 'Mr Moyers', 'I must say that I think I have better opportunity, however, of finding the necessary funds to pay what, admittedly, will be very, very substantial sums of money', 'We signed one bill', 'or we passed one bill, just a couple of weeks ago in the House of Representatives for $500 million  a half a billion dollars', 'That is just a downpayment, in my opinion', 'But, unlike Governor Reagan, I do not support a boondoggle like the MX missile', 'Ive just gotten a report from the Air Force that indicates that the 30year lifecycle cost of that system is going to be $100 billion', 'The initial cost is about $54 billion, and then when you add in the additional costs  not only the construction of the system, the missiles and the personnel, and so on  when you add in the additional costs over the lifecycle of that system, over $100 billion', 'I would propose to save the taxpayers of this country from that kind of costly boondoggle', 'Well, let me just say that, with regard to that same missile system, I happen to support and believe in the missile, itself', 'But thats not the $54 billion cost that John is talking about', 'Hes talking about that fantastic plan of the Administration to take thousands and thousands of square miles out in the Western states', 'And first, he was going to dig a racetrack and have it going around in the racetrack so it would meet the requirements of SALT II treaty, and now hes decided itll have a straight up and down thing, so it can he both verifiable and yet hideable from the Soviet Union', 'We need the missile, I think, because we are so out of balance strategically that we lack a deterrent to a possible first assault', 'But I am not in favor of the plan that is so costly', 'And therefore, if I only had another second left, Id say that that high school class in a military training  40 of its 80 graduates last year entered the United States service academies; West Point, Annapolis and the Air Force Academy, and to see those young men made me very proud to realize that there are young people in this country that are prepared to go into that kind of a career in service of their country']	['Mr. Corddry

column3: 4)	" I don't think I'd have to go against that pledge. I think one of the problems today with the cities is Federal aid. The mayors that I've talked to in some of our leading cities tell! me that the Federal grants that come with. for a specific cause or a specific objective
column5: such priorities established by a bureaucracy in Washington
column6: that the local government's hands are tied with regard to using that money as they feel could best be used
column7: and for what they think might be the top priority. If they had that money without those government restrictions
column8: every one of them has told me they could make great savings and make far greater use of the money. What I have been advocating is
column9: why don't we start with the Federal Government turning back tax sources to states and local governments
column10: as well as the responsibilities for those programs? Seventy-five percent of the people live in the cities. I don't know of a city in America that doesn't have the kind of problems you're talking about. But
column11: where are we getting the money that the Federal Government is putting out to help them? New York is being taxed for money that will then go to Detroit. But Detroit is being taxed for money that
column12: let's say
column13: will go to Chicago
column14: while Chicago is being taxed to help with the problems in Philadelphia. Wouldn't it make a lot more sense if the government let them keep their own money there in the first place? But there are other things that we can do with the inner cities
column15: and I've believed. I have talked of having zones in those cities that are run down
column16: where there is a high percentage of people on welfare
column17: and offer tax incentives. The government isn't getting a tax now from businesses there because they aren't there
column18: or from individuals who are on welfare rather than working. And why don't we offer incentives for business and industry to start up in those zones? Give them a tax moratorium for a period if they build and develop there. The individuals that would then get jobs - give them a break that encourages them to leave the social welfare programs and go to work. We could have an urban homestead act. We've got thousands and thousands of homes owned by government boarded up
column19: being vandalized
column20: that have been taken in mortgage foreclosures. What if we had a homestead act
column22: for $1 we sell you this house. All have to do is agree to refurbish it
column23: make it habitable
column24: and live in it - just as 100 or more years ago
column25: we did with the open land in this country - urban . or country homesteading.

column2: I recently saw a Princeton University study that indicated that the cities of America - the large cities of this country - are in worse shape today than they were in 1960. It seems to totally belie the claim that I heard President Carter make a few days ago
column3: that he was the first President that had come forth with a real urban strategy to meet the problems of urban America. Incidentally
column5: the crown jewel in that program that he had devised was stolen
column6: I guess
column7: because a conference committee turned down the ambitious plan that he had to increase the amount of money that would be available to the Economic Development Administration for loan guarantees and direct loans and credits. I'm happy to say that
column8: in contrast to that
column9: the Anderson-Lucey platform for America
column10: program for the 80s
column11: has devoted considerable time
column12: and in very specific detail
column13: we have talked about two things that ought to be done to aid urban America. We call
column14: first of all
column15: for the creation of a $4 billion urban reinvestment trust fund to do exactly what you spoke about in your question - to rebuild the streets
column16: to rebuild the cities
column17: the leaking water mains. I was in North Pittsburgh - I think it was a few weeks ago
column18: on my campaign - the water mains in that city had begun to leak
column19: and literally
column20: there wasn't money available to fix them. And until we can begin to recreate the basic infrastructure of the great cities of America
column21: particularly in the upper Midwest and in the Northeast
column22: they simply are not going to provide the kind of economic climate that will enable them to retain industry
column23: enable them to retain the kind of solid industrial base that they need
column24: so that they can provide jobs. We have also provided in our program for a $4 billion Community Trust Fund
column25: and we've told you where the money is coming from. It's going to come from the dedication
column27: of the excise revenues that today are being collected by the Federal Government on alcohol and tobacco. That money
column29: ought to be put into rebuilding the base of our cities. In addition to that
column30: jobs programs to re-employ the youth in our cities would be very high on my priority list
column31: both the Youth Opportunities Act of 1980 and a billion-dollar program that I would recommend to put youth to work in energy projects
column32: in conservation projects
column33: in projects that would carry out some of the great national goals of our country.

column1: Yes. Government claims. John claims that he is making plain where the money will come from. It will come from the pockets of the people. It will come from the pockets of the people who are living in those very areas. And the problem is
column3: State and Local - taking $.44 out of every dollar earned
column4: that the Federal Government has pre-empted too many of the tax sources
column5: and that the cities. if Pittsburgh does not have the money to fix the leaking water mains
column6: it's because the Federal Government has pre-empted. Now
column7: the Federal Government is going to turn around and say
column8: well you have this problem; we will now hand you the money to do it. But the Federal Government doesn't make money. It just takes - from the people. And in my view
column9: this is not the answer to the problem. Stand in the South Bronx as I did
column10: in the spot where Jimmy Carter made his promise that he was going to
column11: with multi-billion dollar programs
column12: refurbish that area that looks like bombed-out London in World War II. I stood there
column13: and I met the people. And I heard them ask just for something that would give them hope. And I believe that
column14: while all of the promises have been broken
column15: they've never been carried out. But I believe that my plan might offer an opportunity for that
column16: if we would move into those areas and let
column17: encourage - with the tax incentive - the private sector
column18: to develop and to create the jobs for the people.

column3: where has the private sector been
column5: during the years that our cities have been deteriorating? It seems to me that to deny the responsibility of the Federal Government to do something about our crumbling cities is to deny the opportunity for one thing: To 55% of the black population of our country that is locked within the inner cities of the metropolitan areas of our country. We simply cannot ignore the fact that
column6: in those cities today
column7: we have 55% youth unemployment among black and Hispanic youth. And why is that? It's because they have lost their industry. And why have they lost their industry? It's because they no longer present the kind of viable economic climate that makes it possible for industry to remain there
column8: or to locate there. I think Government has a responsibility to find jobs for the youth of this country
column9: and that the place to start is to assist in the very important and necessary task of helping cities rebuild.

column3: 4)	" I don't think I'd have to go against that pledge. I think one of the problems today with the cities is Federal aid. The mayors that I've talked to in some of our leading cities tell! me that the Federal grants that come with. for a specific cause or a specific objective
column5: such priorities established by a bureaucracy in Washington
column6: that the local government's hands are tied with regard to using that money as they feel could best be used
column7: and for what they think might be the top priority. If they had that money without those government restrictions
column8: every one of them has told me they could make great savings and make far greater use of the money. What I have been advocating is
column9: why don't we start with the Federal Government turning back tax sources to states and local governments
column10: as well as the responsibilities for those programs? Seventy-five percent of the people live in the cities. I don't know of a city in America that doesn't have the kind of problems you're talking about. But
column11: where are we getting the money that the Federal Government is putting out to help them? New York is being taxed for money that will then go to Detroit. But Detroit is being taxed for money that

column15: and I've believed. I have talked of having zones in those cities that are run down
column16: where there is a high percentage of people on welfare
column17: and offer tax incentives. The government isn't getting a tax now from businesses there because they aren't there
column18: or from individuals who are on welfare rather than working. And why don't we offer incentives for business and industry to start up in those zones? Give them a tax moratorium for a period if they build and develop there. The individuals that would then get jobs - give them a break that encourages them to leave the social welfare programs and go to work. We could have an urban homestead act. We've got thousands and thousands of homes owned by government boarded up

column20: that have been taken in mortgage foreclosures. What if we had a homestead act

column2: I recently saw a Princeton University study that indicated that the cities of America - the large cities of this country - are in worse shape today than they were in 1960. It seems to totally belie the claim that I heard President Carter make a few days ago
column3: that he was the first President that had come forth with a real urban strategy to meet the problems of urban America. Incidentally
column5: the crown jewel in that program that he had devised was stolen

column8: in contrast to that
column9: the Anderson-Lucey platform for America
column10: program for the 80s
column11: has devoted considerable time
column12: and in very specific detail

column14: first of all
column15: for the creation of a $4 billion urban reinvestment trust fund to do exactly what you spoke about in your question - to rebuild the streets
column16: to rebuild the cities
column17: the leaking water mains. I was in North Pittsburgh - I think it was a few weeks ago
column18: on my campaign - the water mains in that city had begun to leak
column19: and literally
column20: there wasn't money available to fix them. And until we can begin to recreate the basic infrastructure of the great cities of America
column21: particularly in the upper Midwest and in the Northeast
column22: they simply are not going to provide the kind of economic climate that will enable them to retain industry
column23: enable them to retain the kind of solid industrial base that they need
column24: so that they can provide jobs. We have also provided in our program for a $4 billion Community Trust Fund
column25: and we've told you where the money is coming from. It's going to come from the dedication
column27: of the excise revenues that today are being collected by the Federal Government on alcohol and tobacco. That money

column32: in conservation projects

column12: refurbish that area that looks like bombed-out London in World War II. I stood there

column3: where has the private sector been
column5: during the years that our cities have been deteriorating? It seems to me that to deny the responsibility of the Federal Government to do something about our crumbling cities is to deny the opportunity for one thing: To 55% of the black population of our country that is locked within the inner cities of the metropolitan areas of our country. We simply cannot ignore the fact that
column6: in those cities today
column7: we have 55% youth unemployment among black and Hispanic youth. And why is that? It's because they have lost their industry. And why have they lost their industry? It's because they no longer present the kind of viable economic climate that makes it possible for industry to remain there
column8: or to locate there. I think Government has a responsibility to find jobs for the youth of this country
column9: and that the place to start is to assist in the very important and necessary task of helping cities rebuild.

column3: 4)	" I don't think I'd have to go against that pledge. I think one of the problems today with the cities is Federal aid. The mayors that I've talked to in some of our leading cities tell! me that the Federal grants that come with. for a specific cause or a specific objective
column5: such priorities established by a bureaucracy in Washington
column6: that the local government's hands are tied with regard to using that money as they feel could best be used
column7: and for what they think might be the top priority. If they had that money without those government restrictions
column8: every one of them has told me they could make great savings and make far greater use of the money. What I have been advocating is
column9: why don't we start with the Federal Government turning back tax sources to states and local governments
column10: as well as the responsibilities for those programs? Seventy-five percent of the people live in the cities. I don't know of a city in America that doesn't have the kind of problems you're talking about. But
column11: where are we getting the money that the Federal Government is putting out to help them? New York is being taxed for money that will then go to Detroit. But Detroit is being taxed for money that
column12: let's say
column13: will go to Chicago
column14: while Chicago is being taxed to help with the problems in Philadelphia. Wouldn't it make a lot more sense if the government let them keep their own money there in the first place? But there are other things that we can do with the inner cities
column15: and I've believed. I have talked of having zones in those cities that are run down
column16: where there is a high percentage of people on welfare
column17: and offer tax incentives. The government isn't getting a tax now from businesses there because they aren't there
column18: or from individuals who are on welfare rather than working. And why don't we offer incentives for business and industry to start up in those zones? Give them a tax moratorium for a period if they build and develop there. The individuals that would then get jobs - give them a break that encourages them to leave the social welfare programs and go to work. We could have an urban homestead act. We've got thousands and thousands of homes owned by government boarded up
column19: being vandalized
column20: that have been taken in mortgage foreclosures. What if we had a homestead act
column22: for $1 we sell you this house. All have to do is agree to refurbish it
column23: make it habitable
column24: and live in it - just as 100 or more years ago
column25: we did with the open land in this country - urban . or country homesteading.

column2: I recently saw a Princeton University study that indicated that the cities of America - the large cities of this country - are in worse shape today than they were in 1960. It seems to totally belie the claim that I heard President Carter make a few days ago
column3: that he was the first President that had come forth with a real urban strategy to meet the problems of urban America. Incidentally
column5: the crown jewel in that program that he had devised was stolen
column6: I guess
column7: because a conference committee turned down the ambitious plan that he had to increase the amount of money that would be available to the Economic Development Administration for loan guarantees and direct loans and credits. I'm happy to say that
column8: in contrast to that
column9: the Anderson-Lucey platform for America
column10: program for the 80s
column11: has devoted considerable time
column12: and in very specific detail
column13: we have talked about two things that ought to be done to aid urban America. We call
column14: first of all
column15: for the creation of a $4 billion urban reinvestment trust fund to do exactly what you spoke about in your question - to rebuild the streets
column16: to rebuild the cities
column17: the leaking water mains. I was in North Pittsburgh - I think it was a few weeks ago
column18: on my campaign - the water mains in that city had begun to leak
column19: and literally
column20: there wasn't money available to fix them. And until we can begin to recreate the basic infrastructure of the great cities of America
column21: particularly in the upper Midwest and in the Northeast
column22: they simply are not going to provide the kind of economic climate that will enable them to retain industry
column23: enable them to retain the kind of solid industrial base that they need
column24: so that they can provide jobs. We have also provided in our program for a $4 billion Community Trust Fund
column25: and we've told you where the money is coming from. It's going to come from the dedication
column27: of the excise revenues that today are being collected by the Federal Government on alcohol and tobacco. That money
column29: ought to be put into rebuilding the base of our cities. In addition to that
column30: jobs programs to re-employ the youth in our cities would be very high on my priority list
column31: both the Youth Opportunities Act of 1980 and a billion-dollar program that I would recommend to put youth to work in energy projects
column32: in conservation projects
column33: in projects that would carry out some of the great national goals of our country.

column1: Yes. Government claims. John claims that he is making plain where the money will come from. It will come from the pockets of the people. It will come from the pockets of the people who are living in those very areas. And the problem is
column3: State and Local - taking $.44 out of every dollar earned
column4: that the Federal Government has pre-empted too many of the tax sources
column5: and that the cities. if Pittsburgh does not have the money to fix the leaking water mains
column6: it's because the Federal Government has pre-empted. Now
column7: the Federal Government is going to turn around and say
column8: well you have this problem; we will now hand you the money to do it. But the Federal Government doesn't make money. It just takes - from the people. And in my view
column9: this is not the answer to the problem. Stand in the South Bronx as I did
column10: in the spot where Jimmy Carter made his promise that he was going to
column11: with multi-billion dollar programs
column12: refurbish that area that looks like bombed-out London in World War II. I stood there
column13: and I met the people. And I heard them ask just for something that would give them hope. And I believe that
column14: while all of the promises have been broken
column15: they've never been carried out. But I believe that my plan might offer an opportunity for that
column16: if we would move into those areas and let
column17: encourage - with the tax incentive - the private sector
column18: to develop and to create the jobs for the people.

column3: where has the private sector been
column5: during the years that our cities have been deteriorating? It seems to me that to deny the responsibility of the Federal Government to do something about our crumbling cities is to deny the opportunity for one thing: To 55% of the black population of our country that is locked within the inner cities of the metropolitan areas of our country. We simply cannot ignore the fact that
column6: in those cities today
column7: we have 55% youth unemployment among black and Hispanic youth. And why is that? It's because they have lost their industry. And why have they lost their industry? It's because they no longer present the kind of viable economic climate that makes it possible for industry to remain there
column8: or to locate there. I think Government has a responsibility to find jobs for the youth of this country
column9: and that the place to start is to assist in the very important and necessary task of helping cities rebuild.

column3: 5)	" Miss Quinn
column4: I would be very happy to accept the challenge of your question tonight
column5: to tell the voters of this country exactly what I think it's going to cost
column6: because I believe that all too often in past elections
column7: politicians have simply been promising people things that they cannot deliver. When these Presidential Debates were held just four years ago
column8: I remember the incumbent President
column9: who was willing to debate
column10: President Ford
column11: telling the American people that they simply ought not to vote for somebody who promised more than they could deliver. Well
column12: we've seen what has happened. We haven't gotten either the economies in Government that were promised; we haven't gotten the 4% inflation that we were supposed to get at the end of Mr. Carter's first term. Instead we had
column13: I think
column14: in the second quarter
column15: a Consumer Price Index registering around 12%. And nobody really knows
column16: with the latest increase in the Wholesale Price Index - that's about 18% on an annualized basis - what it's going to be. Let me say this. I think my programs are far less inflationary than those of Governor Reagan. His own running mate
column17: when he was running for the Presidency
column18: said that they would cost 30% inflation inside of two years
column19: and he cited his leading economic advisor
column20: a very distinguished economist
column22: as the source of that information. He went so far as to call it ""brutal economics."" I've been very careful - I have been very careful in saying that what I'm going to do is to bring Federal spending under control first. I would like to stand here and promise the American people a tax cut
column23: as Governor Reagan has done. But
column24: you know
column25: it's gotten to be about $122 difference. Somebody worked it out. And they figured out that between the tax cut that Governor Reagan is promising the American people
column26: and the tax cut that Jimmy Carter is promising in 198I
column27: his is worth about $122 more. So you
column29: are out there on the auction block
column30: and these two candidates are bidding for your votes. And one is going to give you $122 more if you happen to be in that range of about a $20
column31: 000-a-year income. I'm going to wait until I see that that inflation rate is going down
column32: before I even begin to phase in the business tax cuts that I've talked about. But I think
column34: they would be far less inflationary than the consumption-oriented tax cut that Governor Reagan is recommending.

column2: I don't have to. I've done it. We have a back-up paper to my economic speech of a couple of weeks ago in Chicago
column3: that gives all of the figures. And we used - yes
column4: we used - the Senate Budget Committee's projections for five years
column5: which are based on an average inflation rate of 7.5% - which
column6: I think
column7: that under our plan
column8: can be eliminated. And eliminated probably more quickly than our plan
column9: but we wanted to be so conservative with it
column10: that people would see how. how well it could be done. Now
column11: John's been in the Congress for 20 years. And John tells us that first
column12: we've got to reduce spending before we can reduce taxes. Well
column13: if you've got a kid that's extravagant
column14: you can lecture him all you want to about his extravagance. Or you can cut his allowance and achieve the same end much quicker. But Government has never reduced Government does not tax to get the money it needs. Government always needs the money it gets. And when John talks about his non-inflationary plan
column15: as far as I have been able to learn
column16: there are 88 proposals in it that call for additional Government spending programs. Now
column17: I speak with some confidence of our plan
column18: because I took over a state - California - 10% of the population of this nation - a state that
column19: if it were a nation
column20: would be the seventh-ranking economic power in the world. And that state we controlled spending. We cut the rate of increase in spending in half. But at the same time
column21: we gave back to the people of California - in tax rebates
column23: tax cuts - $5.7 billion. I vetoed 993 measures without having a veto overturned. And among those vetoes
column24: I stopped $16 billion in additional spending. And the funny thing was that California
column25: which is normally above the national average in inflation and unemployment
column26: for those six years for the first time
column27: was below the national average in both inflation and unemployment. We have considered inflation in our figures. We deliberately took figures that we
column29: believed were too conservative. I believe the budget can be balanced by 1982 or 1983
column30: and it is a combination of planned reduction of the tax increase that Carter has built into the economy
column31: and that's what he's counting on for his plan. But he's going to get a half-a-trillion dollars more over the next five years that he can use for additional programs
column32: or hopefully
column34: balancing the budget. We believe that that's too much additional money to take out of the pockets of the people.

column2: I'm not here to debate Governor Reagan's record as Governor. This is 1980 and not 1966. But I do know that
column3: despite his pledge to reduce state Government spending
column4: that it rose from $4.6 billion when he took office in 1967
column5: to $10.2 billion during his eight years in office. Spending
column6: in other words. more than doubled
column7: and it rose at a faster rate than spending was rising in the Federal Government. But on his very optimistic figures about his tax cut producing a balanced budget by 1983
column8: and the fact that he is using
column9: he says
column10: the figures of the Senate Budget Committee
column11: that Senate Budget Committee Report does not accommodate all of the Reagan defense plans. It doesn't accommodate the expenditures that he calls for
column12: for accelerated development and deployment of a new manned strategic bomber
column13: for a permanent fleet in the Indian Ocean
column14: for the restoration of the fleet to 600 ships
column15: to the development and deployment of a dedicated modern aircraft interceptor. In other words
column16: I have seen his program costed out to the point where it would amount to more than $300 million a year
column17: just for the military. And I think the figures that he has given are simply not going to stand up.
