column3: 5)	" Miss Quinn
column4: I would be very happy to accept the challenge of your question tonight
column5: to tell the voters of this country exactly what I think it's going to cost
column6: because I believe that all too often in past elections
column7: politicians have simply been promising people things that they cannot deliver. When these Presidential Debates were held just four years ago
column8: I remember the incumbent President
column9: who was willing to debate
column10: President Ford
column11: telling the American people that they simply ought not to vote for somebody who promised more than they could deliver. Well
column12: we've seen what has happened. We haven't gotten either the economies in Government that were promised; we haven't gotten the 4% inflation that we were supposed to get at the end of Mr. Carter's first term. Instead we had
column13: I think
column14: in the second quarter
column15: a Consumer Price Index registering around 12%. And nobody really knows
column16: with the latest increase in the Wholesale Price Index - that's about 18% on an annualized basis - what it's going to be. Let me say this. I think my programs are far less inflationary than those of Governor Reagan. His own running mate
column17: when he was running for the Presidency
column18: said that they would cost 30% inflation inside of two years
column19: and he cited his leading economic advisor
column20: a very distinguished economist
column22: as the source of that information. He went so far as to call it ""brutal economics."" I've been very careful - I have been very careful in saying that what I'm going to do is to bring Federal spending under control first. I would like to stand here and promise the American people a tax cut
column23: as Governor Reagan has done. But
column24: you know
column25: it's gotten to be about $122 difference. Somebody worked it out. And they figured out that between the tax cut that Governor Reagan is promising the American people
column26: and the tax cut that Jimmy Carter is promising in 198I
column27: his is worth about $122 more. So you
column29: are out there on the auction block
column30: and these two candidates are bidding for your votes. And one is going to give you $122 more if you happen to be in that range of about a $20
column31: 000-a-year income. I'm going to wait until I see that that inflation rate is going down
column32: before I even begin to phase in the business tax cuts that I've talked about. But I think
column34: they would be far less inflationary than the consumption-oriented tax cut that Governor Reagan is recommending.

column2: I don't have to. I've done it. We have a back-up paper to my economic speech of a couple of weeks ago in Chicago
column3: that gives all of the figures. And we used - yes
column4: we used - the Senate Budget Committee's projections for five years
column5: which are based on an average inflation rate of 7.5% - which
column6: I think
column7: that under our plan
column8: can be eliminated. And eliminated probably more quickly than our plan
column9: but we wanted to be so conservative with it
column10: that people would see how. how well it could be done. Now
column11: John's been in the Congress for 20 years. And John tells us that first
column12: we've got to reduce spending before we can reduce taxes. Well
column13: if you've got a kid that's extravagant
column14: you can lecture him all you want to about his extravagance. Or you can cut his allowance and achieve the same end much quicker. But Government has never reduced Government does not tax to get the money it needs. Government always needs the money it gets. And when John talks about his non-inflationary plan
column15: as far as I have been able to learn
column16: there are 88 proposals in it that call for additional Government spending programs. Now
column17: I speak with some confidence of our plan
column18: because I took over a state - California - 10% of the population of this nation - a state that
column19: if it were a nation
column20: would be the seventh-ranking economic power in the world. And that state we controlled spending. We cut the rate of increase in spending in half. But at the same time
column21: we gave back to the people of California - in tax rebates
column23: tax cuts - $5.7 billion. I vetoed 993 measures without having a veto overturned. And among those vetoes
column24: I stopped $16 billion in additional spending. And the funny thing was that California
column25: which is normally above the national average in inflation and unemployment
column26: for those six years for the first time
column27: was below the national average in both inflation and unemployment. We have considered inflation in our figures. We deliberately took figures that we
column29: believed were too conservative. I believe the budget can be balanced by 1982 or 1983
column30: and it is a combination of planned reduction of the tax increase that Carter has built into the economy
column31: and that's what he's counting on for his plan. But he's going to get a half-a-trillion dollars more over the next five years that he can use for additional programs
column32: or hopefully
column34: balancing the budget. We believe that that's too much additional money to take out of the pockets of the people.

column2: I'm not here to debate Governor Reagan's record as Governor. This is 1980 and not 1966. But I do know that
column3: despite his pledge to reduce state Government spending
column4: that it rose from $4.6 billion when he took office in 1967
column5: to $10.2 billion during his eight years in office. Spending
column6: in other words. more than doubled
column7: and it rose at a faster rate than spending was rising in the Federal Government. But on his very optimistic figures about his tax cut producing a balanced budget by 1983
column8: and the fact that he is using
column9: he says
column10: the figures of the Senate Budget Committee
column11: that Senate Budget Committee Report does not accommodate all of the Reagan defense plans. It doesn't accommodate the expenditures that he calls for
column12: for accelerated development and deployment of a new manned strategic bomber
column13: for a permanent fleet in the Indian Ocean
column14: for the restoration of the fleet to 600 ships
column15: to the development and deployment of a dedicated modern aircraft interceptor. In other words
column16: I have seen his program costed out to the point where it would amount to more than $300 million a year
column17: just for the military. And I think the figures that he has given are simply not going to stand up.

column3: and some people make up figures. And John has just made up some very interesting figures. We took the Senate report
column4: of course. But we did factor in our own ideas with regard to increases in the projected military spending that we believe would
column6: do what is necessary. Now also
column7: with regard to the figures about California. The truth of the matter is
column8: we did cut the increase in spending in half. It at the John doesn't quite realize - he's never held an executive position of that kind. And I think being Governor of California is probably the closest thing to the Presidency
column9: if that's possible
column10: of any executive job in America today - because it is the most populous state. And I can only tell him that we reduced
column11: in proportion of other states
column12: the per capita spending
column13: the per capita size of Government - we only increased the size of Government one-twelfth what it had increased in the preceding eight years. And one journal
column14: the San Francisco Chronicle
column15: a respected newspaper
column16: said there was no question about the fact that Governor Reagan had prevented the State of California from going bankrupt.

column3: 5)	" Miss Quinn
column4: I would be very happy to accept the challenge of your question tonight
column5: to tell the voters of this country exactly what I think it's going to cost
column6: because I believe that all too often in past elections
column7: politicians have simply been promising people things that they cannot deliver. When these Presidential Debates were held just four years ago
column8: I remember the incumbent President
column9: who was willing to debate
column10: President Ford
column11: telling the American people that they simply ought not to vote for somebody who promised more than they could deliver. Well
column12: we've seen what has happened. We haven't gotten either the economies in Government that were promised; we haven't gotten the 4% inflation that we were supposed to get at the end of Mr. Carter's first term. Instead we had
column13: I think
column14: in the second quarter
column15: a Consumer Price Index registering around 12%. And nobody really knows
column16: with the latest increase in the Wholesale Price Index - that's about 18% on an annualized basis - what it's going to be. Let me say this. I think my programs are far less inflationary than those of Governor Reagan. His own running mate
column17: when he was running for the Presidency
column18: said that they would cost 30% inflation inside of two years
column19: and he cited his leading economic advisor
column20: a very distinguished economist
column22: as the source of that information. He went so far as to call it ""brutal economics."" I've been very careful - I have been very careful in saying that what I'm going to do is to bring Federal spending under control first. I would like to stand here and promise the American people a tax cut
column23: as Governor Reagan has done. But
column24: you know
column25: it's gotten to be about $122 difference. Somebody worked it out. And they figured out that between the tax cut that Governor Reagan is promising the American people
column26: and the tax cut that Jimmy Carter is promising in 198I
column27: his is worth about $122 more. So you
column29: are out there on the auction block
column30: and these two candidates are bidding for your votes. And one is going to give you $122 more if you happen to be in that range of about a $20
column31: 000-a-year income. I'm going to wait until I see that that inflation rate is going down
column32: before I even begin to phase in the business tax cuts that I've talked about. But I think
column34: they would be far less inflationary than the consumption-oriented tax cut that Governor Reagan is recommending.

column2: I don't have to. I've done it. We have a back-up paper to my economic speech of a couple of weeks ago in Chicago
column3: that gives all of the figures. And we used - yes
column4: we used - the Senate Budget Committee's projections for five years
column5: which are based on an average inflation rate of 7.5% - which
column6: I think
column7: that under our plan
column8: can be eliminated. And eliminated probably more quickly than our plan
column9: but we wanted to be so conservative with it
column10: that people would see how. how well it could be done. Now
column11: John's been in the Congress for 20 years. And John tells us that first
column12: we've got to reduce spending before we can reduce taxes. Well
column13: if you've got a kid that's extravagant
column14: you can lecture him all you want to about his extravagance. Or you can cut his allowance and achieve the same end much quicker. But Government has never reduced Government does not tax to get the money it needs. Government always needs the money it gets. And when John talks about his non-inflationary plan
column15: as far as I have been able to learn
column16: there are 88 proposals in it that call for additional Government spending programs. Now
column17: I speak with some confidence of our plan
column18: because I took over a state - California - 10% of the population of this nation - a state that
column19: if it were a nation
column20: would be the seventh-ranking economic power in the world. And that state we controlled spending. We cut the rate of increase in spending in half. But at the same time
column21: we gave back to the people of California - in tax rebates
column23: tax cuts - $5.7 billion. I vetoed 993 measures without having a veto overturned. And among those vetoes
column24: I stopped $16 billion in additional spending. And the funny thing was that California
column25: which is normally above the national average in inflation and unemployment
column26: for those six years for the first time
column27: was below the national average in both inflation and unemployment. We have considered inflation in our figures. We deliberately took figures that we
column29: believed were too conservative. I believe the budget can be balanced by 1982 or 1983
column30: and it is a combination of planned reduction of the tax increase that Carter has built into the economy
column31: and that's what he's counting on for his plan. But he's going to get a half-a-trillion dollars more over the next five years that he can use for additional programs
column32: or hopefully
column34: balancing the budget. We believe that that's too much additional money to take out of the pockets of the people.

column2: I'm not here to debate Governor Reagan's record as Governor. This is 1980 and not 1966. But I do know that
column3: despite his pledge to reduce state Government spending
column4: that it rose from $4.6 billion when he took office in 1967
column5: to $10.2 billion during his eight years in office. Spending
column6: in other words. more than doubled
column7: and it rose at a faster rate than spending was rising in the Federal Government. But on his very optimistic figures about his tax cut producing a balanced budget by 1983
column8: and the fact that he is using
column9: he says
column10: the figures of the Senate Budget Committee
column11: that Senate Budget Committee Report does not accommodate all of the Reagan defense plans. It doesn't accommodate the expenditures that he calls for
column12: for accelerated development and deployment of a new manned strategic bomber
column13: for a permanent fleet in the Indian Ocean
column14: for the restoration of the fleet to 600 ships
column15: to the development and deployment of a dedicated modern aircraft interceptor. In other words
column16: I have seen his program costed out to the point where it would amount to more than $300 million a year
column17: just for the military. And I think the figures that he has given are simply not going to stand up.

column3: and some people make up figures. And John has just made up some very interesting figures. We took the Senate report
column4: of course. But we did factor in our own ideas with regard to increases in the projected military spending that we believe would
column6: do what is necessary. Now also
column7: with regard to the figures about California. The truth of the matter is
column8: we did cut the increase in spending in half. It at the John doesn't quite realize - he's never held an executive position of that kind. And I think being Governor of California is probably the closest thing to the Presidency
column9: if that's possible
column10: of any executive job in America today - because it is the most populous state. And I can only tell him that we reduced
column11: in proportion of other states
column12: the per capita spending
column13: the per capita size of Government - we only increased the size of Government one-twelfth what it had increased in the preceding eight years. And one journal
column14: the San Francisco Chronicle
column15: a respected newspaper
column16: said there was no question about the fact that Governor Reagan had prevented the State of California from going bankrupt.

column3: 5)	" Miss Quinn
column4: I would be very happy to accept the challenge of your question tonight
column5: to tell the voters of this country exactly what I think it's going to cost
column6: because I believe that all too often in past elections
column7: politicians have simply been promising people things that they cannot deliver. When these Presidential Debates were held just four years ago
column8: I remember the incumbent President
column9: who was willing to debate
column10: President Ford
column11: telling the American people that they simply ought not to vote for somebody who promised more than they could deliver. Well
column12: we've seen what has happened. We haven't gotten either the economies in Government that were promised; we haven't gotten the 4% inflation that we were supposed to get at the end of Mr. Carter's first term. Instead we had
column13: I think
column14: in the second quarter
column15: a Consumer Price Index registering around 12%. And nobody really knows
column16: with the latest increase in the Wholesale Price Index - that's about 18% on an annualized basis - what it's going to be. Let me say this. I think my programs are far less inflationary than those of Governor Reagan. His own running mate
column17: when he was running for the Presidency
column18: said that they would cost 30% inflation inside of two years
column19: and he cited his leading economic advisor
column20: a very distinguished economist
column22: as the source of that information. He went so far as to call it ""brutal economics."" I've been very careful - I have been very careful in saying that what I'm going to do is to bring Federal spending under control first. I would like to stand here and promise the American people a tax cut
column23: as Governor Reagan has done. But
column24: you know
column25: it's gotten to be about $122 difference. Somebody worked it out. And they figured out that between the tax cut that Governor Reagan is promising the American people
column26: and the tax cut that Jimmy Carter is promising in 198I
column27: his is worth about $122 more. So you
column29: are out there on the auction block
column30: and these two candidates are bidding for your votes. And one is going to give you $122 more if you happen to be in that range of about a $20
column31: 000-a-year income. I'm going to wait until I see that that inflation rate is going down
column32: before I even begin to phase in the business tax cuts that I've talked about. But I think
column34: they would be far less inflationary than the consumption-oriented tax cut that Governor Reagan is recommending.

column2: I don't have to. I've done it. We have a back-up paper to my economic speech of a couple of weeks ago in Chicago
column3: that gives all of the figures. And we used - yes
column4: we used - the Senate Budget Committee's projections for five years
column5: which are based on an average inflation rate of 7.5% - which
column6: I think
column7: that under our plan
column8: can be eliminated. And eliminated probably more quickly than our plan
column9: but we wanted to be so conservative with it
column10: that people would see how. how well it could be done. Now
column11: John's been in the Congress for 20 years. And John tells us that first
column12: we've got to reduce spending before we can reduce taxes. Well
column13: if you've got a kid that's extravagant
column14: you can lecture him all you want to about his extravagance. Or you can cut his allowance and achieve the same end much quicker. But Government has never reduced Government does not tax to get the money it needs. Government always needs the money it gets. And when John talks about his non-inflationary plan
column15: as far as I have been able to learn
column16: there are 88 proposals in it that call for additional Government spending programs. Now
column17: I speak with some confidence of our plan
column18: because I took over a state - California - 10% of the population of this nation - a state that
column19: if it were a nation
column20: would be the seventh-ranking economic power in the world. And that state we controlled spending. We cut the rate of increase in spending in half. But at the same time
column21: we gave back to the people of California - in tax rebates
column23: tax cuts - $5.7 billion. I vetoed 993 measures without having a veto overturned. And among those vetoes
column24: I stopped $16 billion in additional spending. And the funny thing was that California
column25: which is normally above the national average in inflation and unemployment
column26: for those six years for the first time
column27: was below the national average in both inflation and unemployment. We have considered inflation in our figures. We deliberately took figures that we
column29: believed were too conservative. I believe the budget can be balanced by 1982 or 1983
column30: and it is a combination of planned reduction of the tax increase that Carter has built into the economy
column31: and that's what he's counting on for his plan. But he's going to get a half-a-trillion dollars more over the next five years that he can use for additional programs
column32: or hopefully
column34: balancing the budget. We believe that that's too much additional money to take out of the pockets of the people.

column2: I'm not here to debate Governor Reagan's record as Governor. This is 1980 and not 1966. But I do know that
column3: despite his pledge to reduce state Government spending
column4: that it rose from $4.6 billion when he took office in 1967
column5: to $10.2 billion during his eight years in office. Spending
column6: in other words. more than doubled
column7: and it rose at a faster rate than spending was rising in the Federal Government. But on his very optimistic figures about his tax cut producing a balanced budget by 1983
column8: and the fact that he is using
column9: he says
column10: the figures of the Senate Budget Committee
column11: that Senate Budget Committee Report does not accommodate all of the Reagan defense plans. It doesn't accommodate the expenditures that he calls for
column12: for accelerated development and deployment of a new manned strategic bomber
column13: for a permanent fleet in the Indian Ocean
column14: for the restoration of the fleet to 600 ships
column15: to the development and deployment of a dedicated modern aircraft interceptor. In other words
column16: I have seen his program costed out to the point where it would amount to more than $300 million a year
column17: just for the military. And I think the figures that he has given are simply not going to stand up.

column3: and some people make up figures. And John has just made up some very interesting figures. We took the Senate report
column4: of course. But we did factor in our own ideas with regard to increases in the projected military spending that we believe would
column6: do what is necessary. Now also
column7: with regard to the figures about California. The truth of the matter is
column8: we did cut the increase in spending in half. It at the John doesn't quite realize - he's never held an executive position of that kind. And I think being Governor of California is probably the closest thing to the Presidency
column9: if that's possible
column10: of any executive job in America today - because it is the most populous state. And I can only tell him that we reduced
column11: in proportion of other states
column12: the per capita spending
column13: the per capita size of Government - we only increased the size of Government one-twelfth what it had increased in the preceding eight years. And one journal
column14: the San Francisco Chronicle
column15: a respected newspaper
column16: said there was no question about the fact that Governor Reagan had prevented the State of California from going bankrupt.

column3: 6)	" Oh
column4: I'm it's my question. But whether I agree or disagree with some individual
column6: or how he may say it
column7: I don't think there's any way that we can suggest that because people believe in God and go to church
column8: that they should not want reflected in those people and those causes they support
column9: their own belief in morality
column10: and in the high traditions and principles which we've abandoned so much in this country. Going around this country
column11: I think that I have found a great hunger in America for a spiritual revival. For a belief that law must be based on a higher law. For a return to traditions and values that we once had. Our Government
column12: in its most sacred documents - the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and all - speak of man being created
column13: of a Creator. That we're a nation under God. Now
column14: I have thought for a long time that too many of our churches have been too reluctant to speak up in behalf of what they believe is proper in Government
column15: and they have been too too lax in interfering
column16: in recent years
column17: with Government's invasion of the family itself
column18: putting itself between parent and child. I vetoed a number of bills of that kind myself
column19: when I was in California. Now
column20: whether it is rightful
column22: for anyone to advocate that someone should not be elected or not
column23: I won't take a position on that. But I do believe that no one in this country should be denied the right to express themselves
column24: or to even try to persuade others to follow their leader. That's what elections are all about.

column2: certainly the church has the right to take a position on moral issues. But to try
column3: as occurred in the case that you mentioned - that specific case - to try to tell the parishioners of any church
column6: or for whom they should vote
column7: I think violates the principle of separation of church and state. Now
column8: Governor Reagan is running on a platform that calls for a Constitutional amendment banning abortion. I think that is a moral issue that ought to be left to the freedom of conscience of the individual. And for the state to interfere with a Constitutional amendment
column9: and tell a woman that she must carry that pregnancy to term
column10: regardless of her personal belief
column11: that
column12: I think
column13: violates freedom of conscience as much as anything that I can think of. And he is also running on a platform that suggests a litmus test for the selection of judges - that only judges that hold a certain
column14: quote
column15: ""view
column16: on the sanctity of family life
column17: ought to be appointed to the Federal Judiciary
column18: one of the three great independent branches of our Government. No. I believe in freedom of choice. I don't believe in Constitutional Amendments that would interfere with that. I don't believe in trying to legislate new tests for the selection of the Federal Judiciary. On the Amendment that you mentioned
column19: I abandoned it 15 years ago. And I have said freely
column20: all over this country
column21: that it was a mistake for me or anyone to ever try to put the Judeo-Christian heritage of this country
column23: and important as my religious faith is to me - it's a very deeply personal matter. But for me to try
column24: in this very pluralistic society of ours
column25: to try to frame any definition
column26: whatever
column27: of what that belief should be
column29: not once
column30: but twice - in 1971 - I voted on the floor of the House of Representatives against a Constitutional amendment that tried to bring prayer back into the public schools. I think mother ought to whisper to Johnny and to Susie
column31: as they button their coats in the morning and leave for the classroom
column32: ""Be sure to say a prayer before you start your day's work."" But I don't think that the state
column36: should try to compose that prayer for a child to recite.

column1: The litmus test that John says is in the Republican platform
column2: says no more than the judges to be appointed should have a respect for innocent life. Now
column3: I don't think that's a bad idea. I think all of us should have a respect for innocent life. With regard to the freedom of the individual for choice with regard to abortion
column4: there's one individual who's not being considered at all. That's the one who is being aborted. And I've noticed that everybody that is for abortion has already been born. I I think that
column6: I know this is a difficult and an emotional problem
column7: and many people sincerely feel on both sides of this
column8: but I do believe that maybe we could find the answer through medical evidence
column9: if we would determine once and for all
column10: is an unborn child a human being? I happen to believe it is.

column1: I also think that that unborn child has a right to be wanted. And I also believe
column3: that the most personal intimate decision that any woman is ever called upon to make is the decision as to whether or not she shall carry a pregnancy to term. And for the state to interfere in that decision
column6: for the state to try to take over in that situation
column7: and by edict
column8: command what the individual shall do
column9: and substitute itself for that individual's conscience
column10: for her right to consult her rabbi
column11: her minister
column12: her priest

they should not want reflected in those people and those causes they support, their own belief in morality, and in the high traditions and principles which weve abandoned so much in this country', 'Going around this country, I think that I have found a great hunger in America for a spiritual revival', 'For a belief that law must be based on a higher law', 'For a return to traditions and values that we once had', 'Our Government, in its most sacred documents  the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and all  speak of man being created, of a Creator', 'That were a nation under God', 'Now, I have thought for a long time that too many of our churches have been too reluctant to speak up in behalf of what they believe is proper in Government, and they have been too too lax in interfering, in recent years, with Governments invasion of the family itself, putting itself between parent and child', 'I vetoed a number of bills of that kind myself, when I was in California', 'Now, whether it is rightful, on a single issue, for anyone to advocate that someone should not be elected or not, I wont take a position on that', 'But I do believe that no one in this country should be denied the right to express themselves, or to even try to persuade others to follow their leader', 'Thats what elections are all about', 'Ms Golden, certainly the church has the right to take a position on moral issues', 'But to try, as occurred in the case that you mentioned  that specific case  to try to tell the parishioners of any church, of any denomination, how they should vote, or for whom they should vote, I think violates the principle of separation of church and state', 'Now, Governor Reagan is running on a platform that calls for a Constitutional amendment banning abortion', 'I think that is a moral issue that ought to be left to the freedom of conscience of the individual', 'And for the state to interfere with a Constitutional amendment, and tell a woman that she must carry that pregnancy to term, regardless of her personal belief, that, I think, violates freedom of conscience as much as anything that I can think of', 'And he is also running on a platform that suggests a litmus test for the selection of judges  that only judges that hold a certain, quote, view, on the sanctity of family life, ought to be appointed to the Federal Judiciary, one of the three great independent branches of our Government', 'No', 'I believe in freedom of choice', 'I dont believe in Constitutional Amendments that would interfere with that', 'I dont believe in trying to legislate new tests for the selection of the Federal Judiciary', 'On the Amendment that you mentioned, I abandoned it 15 years ago', 'And I have said freely, all over this country, that it was a mistake for me or anyone to ever try to put the JudeoChristian heritage of this country, important as it is, and important as my religious faith is to me  its a very deeply personal matter', 'But for me to try, in this very pluralistic society of ours, to try to frame any definition, whatever, of what that belief should be, is wrong', 'And so, not once, but twice  in 1971  I voted on the floor of the House of Representatives against a Constitutional amendment that tried to bring prayer back into the public schools', 'I think mother ought to whisper to Johnny and to Susie, as they button their coats in the morning and leave for the classroom, Be sure to say a prayer before you start your days work', 'But I dont think that the state, the Board of Regents, a Board of Education, or any state official, should try to compose that prayer for a child to recite', 'The litmus test that John says is in the Republican platform, says no more than the judges to be appointed should have a respect for innocent life', 'Now, I dont think thats a bad idea', 'I think all of us should have a respect for innocent life', 'With regard to the freedom of the individual for choice with regard to abortion, theres one individual whos not being considered at all', 'Thats the one who is being aborted', 'And Ive noticed that everybody that is for abortion has already been born', 'I I think that, technically, I know this is a difficult and an emotional problem, and many people sincerely feel on both sides of this, but I do believe that maybe we could find the answer through medical evidence, if we would determine once and for all, is an unborn child a human being?', 'I happen to believe it is', 'I also think that that unborn child has a right to be wanted', 'And I also believe, sir, that the most personal intimate decision that any woman is ever called upon to make is the decision as to whether or not she shall carry a pregnancy to term', 'And for the state to interfere in that decision, under whatever guise, and with whatever rationale, for the state to try to take over in that situation, and by edict, command what the individual shall do, and substitute itself for that individuals conscience, for her right to consult her rabbi, her minister, her priest, her doctor  any other counselor of her choice  I think goes beyond what we want to ever see accomplished in this country, if we really believe column7: I don't think there's any way that we can suggest that because people believe in God and go to church

column12: in its most sacred documents - the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and all - speak of man being created
column13: of a Creator. That we're a nation under God. Now

column18: putting itself between parent and child. I vetoed a number of bills of that kind myself

column23: I won't take a position on that. But I do believe that no one in this country should be denied the right to express themselves
column24: or to even try to persuade others to follow their leader. That's what elections are all about.

column10: regardless of her personal belief

I don't believe in trying to legislate new tests for the selection of the Federal Judiciary. On the Amendment that you mentioned
column19: I abandoned it 15 years ago. And I have said freely
column20: all over this country

column12: in its most sacred documents - the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and all - speak of man being created
column13: of a Creator. That we're a nation under God. Now
column14: I have thought for a long time that too many of our churches have been too reluctant to speak up in behalf of what they believe is proper in Government
column15: and they have been too too lax in interfering
column16: in recent years
column17: with Government's invasion of the family itself
column18: putting itself between parent and child. I vetoed a number of bills of that kind myself
column19: when I was in California. Now
column20: whether it is rightful
column22: for anyone to advocate that someone should not be elected or not
column23: I won't take a position on that. But I do believe that no one in this country should be denied the right to express themselves
column24: or to even try to persuade others to follow their leader. That's what elections are all about.

column2: certainly the church has the right to take a position on moral issues. But to try
column3: as occurred in the case that you mentioned - that specific case - to try to tell the parishioners of any church
column6: or for whom they should vote
column7: I think violates the principle of separation of church and state. Now
column8: Governor Reagan is running on a platform that calls for a Constitutional amendment banning abortion. I think that is a moral issue that ought to be left to the freedom of conscience of the individual. And for the state to interfere with a Constitutional amendment
column9: and tell a woman that she must carry that pregnancy to term
column10: regardless of her personal belief
column11: that
column12: I think
column13: violates freedom of conscience as much as anything that I can think of. And he is also running on a platform that suggests a litmus test for the selection of judges - that only judges that hold a certain
column14: quote
column15: ""view
column16: on the sanctity of family life
column17: ought to be appointed to the Federal Judiciary
column18: one of the three great independent branches of our Government. No. I believe in freedom of choice. I don't believe in Constitutional Amendments that would interfere with that. I don't believe in trying to legislate new tests for the selection of the Federal Judiciary. On the Amendment that you mentioned
column19: I abandoned it 15 years ago. And I have said freely
column20: all over this country
column21: that it was a mistake for me or anyone to ever try to put the Judeo-Christian heritage of this country
column23: and important as my religious faith is to me - it's a very deeply personal matter. But for me to try
column24: in this very pluralistic society of ours
column25: to try to frame any definition
column26: whatever
column27: of what that belief should be
column29: not once
column30: but twice - in 1971 - I voted on the floor of the House of Representatives against a Constitutional amendment that tried to bring prayer back into the public schools. I think mother ought to whisper to Johnny and to Susie
column31: as they button their coats in the morning and leave for the classroom
column32: ""Be sure to say a prayer before you start your day's work."" But I don't think that the state
column36: should try to compose that prayer for a child to recite.

column1: The litmus test that John says is in the Republican platform
column2: says no more than the judges to be appointed should have a respect for innocent life. Now
column3: I don't think that's a bad idea. I think all of us should have a respect for innocent life. With regard to the freedom of the individual for choice with regard to abortion
column4: there's one individual who's not being considered at all. That's the one who is being aborted. And I've noticed that everybody that is for abortion has already been born. I I think that
column6: I know this is a difficult and an emotional problem
column7: and many people sincerely feel on both sides of this
column8: but I do believe that maybe we could find the answer through medical evidence
column9: if we would determine once and for all
column10: is an unborn child a human being? I happen to believe it is.

column1: I also think that that unborn child has a right to be wanted. And I also believe
column3: that the most personal intimate decision that any woman is ever called upon to make is the decision as to whether or not she shall carry a pregnancy to term. And for the state to interfere in that decision
column6: for the state to try to take over in that situation
column7: and by edict
column8: command what the individual shall do
column9: and substitute itself for that individual's conscience
column10: for her right to consult her rabbi
column11: her minister
column12: her priest
column13: her doctor - any other counselor of her choice - I think goes beyond what we want to ever see accomplished in this country
column14: if we really believe in the First Amendment: if we really believe in freedom of choice and the right of the individual.

column7: I don't think there's any way that we can suggest that because people believe in God and go to church

column9: their own belief in morality
column10: and in the high traditions and principles which we've abandoned so much in this country. Going around this country
column11: I think that I have found a great hunger in America for a spiritual revival. For a belief that law must be based on a higher law. For a return to traditions and values that we once had. Our Government
column12: in its most sacred documents - the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and all - speak of man being created
column13: of a Creator. That we're a nation under God. Now

column15: and they have been too too lax in interfering
column16: in recent years
column17: with Government's invasion of the family itself
column18: putting itself between parent and child. I vetoed a number of bills of that kind myself
column19: when I was in California. Now
column20: whether it is rightful
column22: for anyone to advocate that someone should not be elected or not
column23: I won't take a position on that. But I do believe that no one in this country should be denied the right to express themselves
column24: or to even try to persuade others to follow their leader. That's what elections are all about.

I don't believe in trying to legislate new tests for the selection of the Federal Judiciary. On the Amendment that you mentioned
column19: I abandoned it 15 years ago. And I have said freely
column20: all over this country
column21: that it was a mistake for me or anyone to ever try to put the Judeo-Christian heritage of this country

column10: is an unborn child a human being? I happen to believe it is.

column3: 7)	" Before beginning my closing remarks
column5: I would just like to remark a concern that I have that we have criticized the failures of the Carter policy here rather considerably
column6: both of us this evening. And there might be some feeling of unfairness about this because he was not here to respond. But I believe it would have been much more unfair to have had John Anderson denied the right to participate in this debate. And I want to express my appreciation to the League of Women Voters for adopting a course with which I believe the great majority of Americans are in agreement. Now
column7: as to my closing remarks: I've always believed that this land was placed here between the two great oceans by some divine plan. That it was placed here to be found by a special kind of people - people who had a special love for freedom and who had the courage to uproot themselves and leave hearth and homeland
column8: and came to what
column9: in the beginning
column10: was the most undeveloped wilderness possible. We came from 100 different corners of the earth. We spoke a multitude of tongues. We landed on this Eastern shore and then went out over the mountains and the prairies and the deserts and the far western mountains to the Pacific
column11: building cities and towns and farms
column12: and schools and churches. If wind
column13: water or fire destroyed them
column14: we built them again. And in so doing
column15: at the same time
column16: we built a new breed of human called an American - a proud
column17: an independent.
column18: and a most compassionate individual
column19: for the most part. Two hundred years ago
column20: Tom Paine
column21: when the 13 tiny colonies were trying to become a nation
column23: we have it in our power to begin the world over again. Today. we're confronted with the horrendous problems that we've discussed here tonight. And some people in high positions of leadership
column24: tell us that the answer is to retreat. That the best is over. That we must cut back. That we must share in an ever-increasing scarcity. That we must
column25: in the failure to be able to protect our national security as it is today
column26: we must not be provocative to any possible adversary. Well
column29: have gone through four wars. We've gone through a Great Depression in our lifetime that literally was worldwide and almost brought us to our knees. But we came through all of those things and we achieved even new heights and new greatness. The living Americans today have fought harder
column30: paid a higher price for freedom
column31: and done more to advance the dignity of man than any people who ever lived on this earth. For 200 years
column32: we've lived in the future
column33: believing that tomorrow would be better than today
column34: and today would be better than yesterday. I still believe that. I'm not running for the Presidency because I believe that I can solve the problems we've discussed tonight. I believe the people of this country can
column36: we can begin the world over again. We can meet our destiny - and that destiny to build a land here that will be
column38: a shining city on a hill. I think we ought to get at it.

column2: President Carter was not right a few weeks ago when he said that the American people were confronted with only two choices
column3: with only two men
column4: and with only two parties. I think you've seen tonight in this debate that Governor Reagan and I have agreed on exactly one thing - we are both against the reimposition of a peacetime draft. We have disagreed
column6: on virtually every other issue. I respect him for showing tonight - for appearing here
column7: and I thank the League of Women Voters for the opportunity that they have given me. I am running for President as an Independent because I believe our country is in trouble. I believe that all of us are going to have to begin to work together to solve our problems. If you think that I am a spoiler
column8: consider these facts: Do you really think that our economy is healthy? Do you really think that 8 million Americans being out of work and the 50% unemployment among the youth of our country are acceptable? Do you really think that our armed forces are really acceptably strong in those areas of conventional capability where they should be? Do you think that our political institutions are working the way they should when literally only half of our citizens vote? I don't think you do think that. And therefore
column9: I think you ought to consider doing something about it
column10: and voting for an Independent in 1980. You know
column11: a generation of office seekers has tried to tell the American people that they could get something for nothing. It's been a time
column12: therefore
column13: of illusion and false hopes
column14: and the longer it continues
column15: the more dangerous it becomes. We've got to stop drifting. What I wish tonight so desperately is that we had had more time to talk about some of the other issues that are so fundamentally important. A great historian
column16: Henry Steele Commager
column17: said that in their lust for victory
column18: neither traditional party is looking beyond November. And he went on to cite three issues that their platforms totally ignore: atomic warfare
column19: Presidential Directive 59 notwithstanding. If we don't resolve that issue
column20: all others become irrelevant. The issue of our natural resources; the right of posterity to inherit the earth
column21: and what kind of earth will it be? The issue of nationalism - the recognition
column23: that every major problem confronting us is global
column24: and cannot be solved by nationalism here or elsewhere - that is chauvinistic
column25: that is parochial
column26: that is as anachronistic as states' rights was in the days of Jefferson Davis. Those are some of the great issues - atomic warfare
column27: the use of our natural resources
column28: and the issue of nationalism - that I intend to be talking about in the remaining six weeks of this campaign
column29: and I dare hope that the American people will be listening and that they will see that an Independent government of John Anderson and Patrick Lucey can give us the kind of coalition government that we need in 1980 to begin to solve our problems. Thank you.

column2: President Carter was not right a few weeks ago when he said that the American people were confronted with only two choices
column3: with only two men
column4: and with only two parties. I think you've seen tonight in this debate that Governor Reagan and I have agreed on exactly one thing - we are both against the reimposition of a peacetime draft. We have disagreed
column6: on virtually every other issue. I respect him for showing tonight - for appearing here
column7: and I thank the League of Women Voters for the opportunity that they have given me. I am running for President as an Independent because I believe our country is in trouble. I believe that all of us are going to have to begin to work together to solve our problems. If you think that I am a spoiler
column8: consider these facts: Do you really think that our economy is healthy? Do you really think that 8 million Americans being out of work and the 50% unemployment among the youth of our country are acceptable? Do you really think that our armed forces are really acceptably strong in those areas of conventional capability where they should be? Do you think that our political institutions are working the way they should when literally only half of our citizens vote? I don't think you do think that. And therefore
column9: I think you ought to consider doing something about it
column10: and voting for an Independent in 1980. You know
column11: a generation of office seekers has tried to tell the American people that they could get something for nothing. It's been a time
column12: therefore
column13: of illusion and false hopes
column14: and the longer it continues
column15: the more dangerous it becomes. We've got to stop drifting. What I wish tonight so desperately is that we had had more time to talk about some of the other issues that are so fundamentally important. A great historian
column16: Henry Steele Commager
column17: said that in their lust for victory
column18: neither traditional party is looking beyond November. And he went on to cite three issues that their platforms totally ignore: atomic warfare
column19: Presidential Directive 59 notwithstanding. If we don't resolve that issue
column20: all others become irrelevant. The issue of our natural resources; the right of posterity to inherit the earth
column21: and what kind of earth will it be? The issue of nationalism - the recognition
column23: that every major problem confronting us is global
column24: and cannot be solved by nationalism here or elsewhere - that is chauvinistic
column25: that is parochial
column26: that is as anachronistic as states' rights was in the days of Jefferson Davis. Those are some of the great issues - atomic warfare
column27: the use of our natural resources
column28: and the issue of nationalism - that I intend to be talking about in the remaining six weeks of this campaign
column29: and I dare hope that the American people will be listening and that they will see that an Independent government of John Anderson and Patrick Lucey can give us the kind of coalition government that we need in 1980 to begin to solve our problems. Thank you.

column6: both of us this evening. And there might be some feeling of unfairness about this because he was not here to respond. And I want to express my appreciation to the League of Women Voters for adopting a course with which I believe the great majority of Americans are in agreement. Now
column7: as to my closing remarks: I've always believed that this land was placed here between the two great oceans by some divine plan. That it was placed here to be found by a special kind of people - people who had a special love for freedom and who had the courage to uproot themselves and leave hearth and homeland
column8: and came to what
column9: in the beginning
column10: was the most undeveloped wilderness possible. We came from 100 different corners of the earth. We spoke a multitude of tongues. We landed on this Eastern shore and then went out over the mountains and the prairies and the deserts and the far western mountains to the Pacific
column11: building cities and towns and farms
column12: and schools and churches. If wind
column13: water or fire destroyed them
column14: we built them again. And in so doing
column15: at the same time
column16: we built a new breed of human called an American - a proud
column17: an independent.
column18: and a most compassionate individual
column19: for the most part. Two hundred years ago
column20: Tom Paine
column21: when the 13 tiny colonies were trying to become a nation

column25: in the failure to be able to protect our national security as it is today

column29: have gone through four wars. We've gone through a Great Depression in our lifetime that literally was worldwide and almost brought us to our knees. But we came through all of those things and we achieved even new heights and new greatness. The living Americans today have fought harder
column30: paid a higher price for freedom
column31: and done more to advance the dignity of man than any people who ever lived on this earth. For 200 years
column32: we've lived in the future

column38: a shining city on a hill. I think we ought to get at it.

column2: President Carter was not right a few weeks ago when he said that the American people were confronted with only two choices
column3: with only two men
column4: and with only two parties. I think you've seen tonight in this debate that Governor Reagan and I have agreed on exactly one thing - we are both against the reimposition of a peacetime draft. We have disagreed
column6: on virtually every other issue. I respect him for showing tonight - for appearing here
column7: and I thank the League of Women Voters for the opportunity that they have given me. I am running for President as an Independent because I believe our country is in trouble. I believe that all of us are going to have to begin to work together to solve our problems. If you think that I am a spoiler
column8: consider these facts: Do you really think that our economy is healthy? Do you really think that 8 million Americans being out of work and the 50% unemployment among the youth of our country are acceptable? Do you really think that our armed forces are really acceptably strong in those areas of conventional capability where they should be? Do you think that our political institutions are working the way they should when literally only half of our citizens vote? I don't think you do think that. And therefore
column9: I think you ought to consider doing something about it
column10: and voting for an Independent in 1980. You know
column11: a generation of office seekers has tried to tell the American people that they could get something for nothing. It's been a time
column12: therefore
column13: of illusion and false hopes
column14: and the longer it continues
column15: the more dangerous it becomes. We've got to stop drifting. What I wish tonight so desperately is that we had had more time to talk about some of the other issues that are so fundamentally important. A great historian
column16: Henry Steele Commager
column17: said that in their lust for victory
column18: neither traditional party is looking beyond November. And he went on to cite three issues that their platforms totally ignore: atomic warfare
column19: Presidential Directive 59 notwithstanding. If we don't resolve that issue
column20: all others become irrelevant. The issue of our natural resources; the right of posterity to inherit the earth
column21: and what kind of earth will it be? The issue of nationalism - the recognition
column23: that every major problem confronting us is global
column24: and cannot be solved by nationalism here or elsewhere - that is chauvinistic
column25: that is parochial
column26: that is as anachronistic as states' rights was in the days of Jefferson Davis. Those are some of the great issues - atomic warfare
column27: the use of our natural resources
column28: and the issue of nationalism - that I intend to be talking about in the remaining six weeks of this campaign
column29: and I dare hope that the American people will be listening and that they will see that an Independent government of John Anderson and Patrick Lucey can give us the kind of coalition government that we need in 1980 to begin to solve our problems. Thank you.

column2: President Carter was not right a few weeks ago when he said that the American people were confronted with only two choices
column3: with only two men
column4: and with only two parties. I think you've seen tonight in this debate that Governor Reagan and I have agreed on exactly one thing - we are both against the reimposition of a peacetime draft. We have disagreed
column6: on virtually every other issue. I respect him for showing tonight - for appearing here
column7: and I thank the League of Women Voters for the opportunity that they have given me. I am running for President as an Independent because I believe our country is in trouble. I believe that all of us are going to have to begin to work together to solve our problems. If you think that I am a spoiler
column8: consider these facts: Do you really think that our economy is healthy? Do you really think that 8 million Americans being out of work and the 50% unemployment among the youth of our country are acceptable? Do you really think that our armed forces are really acceptably strong in those areas of conventional capability where they should be? Do you think that our political institutions are working the way they should when literally only half of our citizens vote? I don't think you do think that. And therefore
column9: I think you ought to consider doing something about it
column10: and voting for an Independent in 1980. You know
column11: a generation of office seekers has tried to tell the American people that they could get something for nothing. It's been a time
column12: therefore
column13: of illusion and false hopes
column14: and the longer it continues
column15: the more dangerous it becomes. We've got to stop drifting. What I wish tonight so desperately is that we had had more time to talk about some of the other issues that are so fundamentally important. A great historian
column16: Henry Steele Commager
column17: said that in their lust for victory
column18: neither traditional party is looking beyond November. And he went on to cite three issues that their platforms totally ignore: atomic warfare
column19: Presidential Directive 59 notwithstanding. If we don't resolve that issue
column20: all others become irrelevant. The issue of our natural resources; the right of posterity to inherit the earth
column21: and what kind of earth will it be? The issue of nationalism - the recognition
column23: that every major problem confronting us is global
column24: and cannot be solved by nationalism here or elsewhere - that is chauvinistic
column25: that is parochial
column26: that is as anachronistic as states' rights was in the days of Jefferson Davis. Those are some of the great issues - atomic warfare
column27: the use of our natural resources
column28: and the issue of nationalism - that I intend to be talking about in the remaining six weeks of this campaign
column29: and I dare hope that the American people will be listening and that they will see that an Independent government of John Anderson and Patrick Lucey can give us the kind of coalition government that we need in 1980 to begin to solve our problems. Thank you.

column7: as to my closing remarks: I've always believed that this land was placed here between the two great oceans by some divine plan. That it was placed here to be found by a special kind of people - people who had a special love for freedom and who had the courage to uproot themselves and leave hearth and homeland
column8: and came to what
column9: in the beginning
column10: was the most undeveloped wilderness possible. We came from 100 different corners of the earth. We spoke a multitude of tongues. We landed on this Eastern shore and then went out over the mountains and the prairies and the deserts and the far western mountains to the Pacific
column11: building cities and towns and farms
column12: and schools and churches. If wind
column13: water or fire destroyed them
column14: we built them again. And in so doing
column15: at the same time
column16: we built a new breed of human called an American - a proud
column17: an independent.
column18: and a most compassionate individual
column19: for the most part. Two hundred years ago
column20: Tom Paine
column21: when the 13 tiny colonies were trying to become a nation
column23: we have it in our power to begin the world over again. Today. we're confronted with the horrendous problems that we've discussed here tonight. And some people in high positions of leadership
column24: tell us that the answer is to retreat. That the best is over. That we must cut back. That we must share in an ever-increasing scarcity. That we must

column29: have gone through four wars. We've gone through a Great Depression in our lifetime that literally was worldwide and almost brought us to our knees. But we came through all of those things and we achieved even new heights and new greatness. The living Americans today have fought harder
column30: paid a higher price for freedom
column31: and done more to advance the dignity of man than any people who ever lived on this earth. For 200 years
column32: we've lived in the future
column33: believing that tomorrow would be better than today
column34: and today would be better than yesterday. I still believe that. I'm not running for the Presidency because I believe that I can solve the problems we've discussed tonight. I believe the people of this country can
column36: we can begin the world over again. We can meet our destiny - and that destiny to build a land here that will be
column38: a shining city on a hill. I think we ought to get at it.

column2: President Carter was not right a few weeks ago when he said that the American people were confronted with only two choices
column3: with only two men
column4: and with only two parties. I think you've seen tonight in this debate that Governor Reagan and I have agreed on exactly one thing - we are both against the reimposition of a peacetime draft. We have disagreed
column6: on virtually every other issue. I respect him for showing tonight - for appearing here
column7: and I thank the League of Women Voters for the opportunity that they have given me. I am running for President as an Independent because I believe our country is in trouble. I believe that all of us are going to have to begin to work together to solve our problems. If you think that I am a spoiler
column8: consider these facts: Do you really think that our economy is healthy? Do you really think that 8 million Americans being out of work and the 50% unemployment among the youth of our country are acceptable? Do you really think that our armed forces are really acceptably strong in those areas of conventional capability where they should be? Do you think that our political institutions are working the way they should when literally only half of our citizens vote? I don't think you do think that. And therefore
column9: I think you ought to consider doing something about it
column10: and voting for an Independent in 1980. You know
column11: a generation of office seekers has tried to tell the American people that they could get something for nothing. It's been a time
column12: therefore
column13: of illusion and false hopes
column14: and the longer it continues
column15: the more dangerous it becomes. We've got to stop drifting. What I wish tonight so desperately is that we had had more time to talk about some of the other issues that are so fundamentally important. A great historian
column16: Henry Steele Commager
column17: said that in their lust for victory
column18: neither traditional party is looking beyond November. And he went on to cite three issues that their platforms totally ignore: atomic warfare
column19: Presidential Directive 59 notwithstanding. If we don't resolve that issue
column20: all others become irrelevant. The issue of our natural resources; the right of posterity to inherit the earth
column21: and what kind of earth will it be? The issue of nationalism - the recognition
column23: that every major problem confronting us is global
column24: and cannot be solved by nationalism here or elsewhere - that is chauvinistic
column25: that is parochial
column26: that is as anachronistic as states' rights was in the days of Jefferson Davis. Those are some of the great issues - atomic warfare
column27: the use of our natural resources
column28: and the issue of nationalism - that I intend to be talking about in the remaining six weeks of this campaign
column29: and I dare hope that the American people will be listening and that they will see that an Independent government of John Anderson and Patrick Lucey can give us the kind of coalition government that we need in 1980 to begin to solve our problems. Thank you.
